results.title: The Milky way
results.creator_credit: I S O and Ruroy Sibley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Universe”.
The stars and constellations of the Milky Way are shown by astronomical photography through the great telescope at Palomar Observatory, Mount Wilson, Harvard College, University of Colorado and the Yerkes Lowell and Lich Observatories. Various types of star clusters and nebular are included and the development of Nova Aquilae 1918 to 1932 is traced.

group_siblings.title: The Depths of space: exterior galaxies

results.title: The Milky way
results.creator_credit: United World Films and ACI Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This film presents a scientist’s conception of how stars were formed. It includes a brief explanation of the Milky Way and shows the telescopes used to study stars, light and radio waves. Suitable for lower secondary level.

group_siblings.title: Over the hill to the moon

results.title: The Milgram reenactment
results.brief_description: In 1961 at Yale University one of the most famous learning experiments in the history of psychology shocked the world.The experiment was an eloquent and sophisticated piece of artifice aimed at convincing the subjects (Milgram named them Teachers) that they really were administering extreme shocks to an unwilling victim. The disturbing results shown that in the context of following orders we are capable of unquestioningly causing the suffering of others. UK conceptual Artist Rod Dickinson in his work has precisely recreated the extraordinary drama that occurred and the troubling questions that it raises about humanity.

results.title: The Mikado
results.creator_credit: Opera Australia, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Virginia Lumsden and Christopher Renshaw
results.brief_description: Acclaimed as Gilbert and Sullivan’s master work, “The Mikado”, after 100 years, is still their most popular opera. This is a beautiful production, directed by Christopher Renshaw, with hundreds of painted fans, huge porcelain urns, and its visual send-ups of Victorian England’s views of the then mysterious Japan. Features singers Robert Eddie (The Mikado), Heather Begg (Katisha), Peter Cousens (Nanki-Poo), Anne-Maree McDonald, Caroline Clack, Jennifer Bermingham as the Three Little Maids, Graeme Ewer (Ko-Ko), and The Australian Opera Chorus. Also features The Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra conducted by Andrew Greene. Recorded live at the Sydney Opera House on 25 February 1987 and produced for television in association with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

results.title: The Migrant experience. Parts 5 and 6 (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, Malcolm Smith, Karl McPhee and Ben Lewin
results.brief_description: A series of six episodes that present a comprehensive history of the role of migration in the development of Australia. Part 5 “Something old, something new.” looks at the search for personal balance between old traditions and new ways. Part 6 “Are you fair dinkum?” explores the changes brought about by an increasingly multicultural society.

results.title: The Migrant experience. Parts 4-6
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Smith, Karl McPhee and Ben Lewin
results.brief_description: A series, made up of six episodes, that gives a comprehensive history of migration to Australia. The first three episodes give a general account of migration over the past 200 years. Parts Four to Six are of greater contemporary interest. They focus on the work of migrants, how their resettlement affected them and the impact they had on Australia.

results.title: The Migrant experience. Parts 3 and 4 (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, Malcolm Smith, Ben Lewin and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description: A series of six episodes that present a comprehensive history of the role of migration in the development of Australia. Part 3 “First encounters” looks at how new immigrants were received. Part 4 “Working” examines the experiences of the “new workforce”.

results.title: The Migrant experience. Parts 1 and 2 (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, Malcolm Smith, Karl McPhee and Ben Lewin
results.brief_description: From a series of six episodes that presents a comprehensive history of the role of migration in the development of Australia. Part 1 “Setting out” looks at the general history of migration to Australia over the past 200 years. Part 2 “Of dreams and reasons” looks at the reasons why people left their homelands and came to Australia.

results.title: The Migrant experience. Parts 1-3
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Smith, Karl McPhee and Ben Lewin
results.brief_description: A series, made up of six episodes, that presents a comprehensive history of the role of migration in the development of Australia’s nationhood. Part One: Setting out - looks at the general history of migration to Australia over 200 years. Part Two: Of dreams and reasons - looks at the reasons why people left their homelands and came to Australia. Part Three: First encounters - looks at how they were received.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Malcolm Smith, Karl McPhee and Ben Lewin

results.title: The Migrant experience
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Smith and Ben Lewin
results.brief_description: A comprehensive look at migrants in Australia, their history, their effect on the country, their problems and their hopes.
